item.title: Development of Cognitive Operations (Piaget)
item.description:
Development of Cognitive Operations (Piaget)

Add
- [ ] conservation failure/emergence - [ ] types of conservation - [ ] classification failure/emergence - [ ] transductive reasoning (until age 7) - [ ] conservation failure/emergence - [ ] varieties and order them (substance precedes volume & weight) - [ ] egocentrism (diminishes by age 8) - [ ] centration/decentration - [ ] perseveration - [ ] animism (ends age 3) - [ ] inductive reasoning - [ ] irreversibility/reversibility

item.title: operation (Piaget)
item.description:
operation (Piaget)

operation
logical manipulation of information

#Term
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: transductive reasoning (Piaget)
item.description:
transductive reasoning (Piaget)

transductive reasoning
making faulty inferences from one specific example to another

Examples

Lucienne Piaget: "It's not afternoon because I haven't had my nap yet!"

Piaget: "Are there more daisies or flowers?"
Subject (age 7): "More daisies."

Notes & Links

  • overgeneralization
    • see "Cognitive Development in Children" for 'generalization'
  • Development …
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: accommodation (Piaget)
item.description:
accommodation (Piaget)

accommodation
the restructuring of old ideas to include new experiences
construction of new logical operations
inverse of assimilation (Piaget)

Term
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: assimilation (Piaget)
item.description:
assimilation (Piaget)

assimilation
reinterpretation of new experiences to fit into old ideas
integrating stimuli into extant knowledge structures
inverse of accommodation (Piaget)

#Term
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: classification (Piaget)
item.description:
classification (Piaget)

classification
the logical operation that things can be organized into groups or categories or classes according to some common characteristic [^1]
typically acquired by 8 yrs., during the concrete operational stage [^1]: Piaget references the "daisy vs. flower" example to illustrate how understanding of nested hierarchies is developed …
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: cognitive equilibrium (Piaget)
item.description:
cognitive equilibrium (Piaget)

Term

cognitive equilibrium
in cognitive theory, a state of mental balance in which people are not confused because they can use their existing thought processes to understand current experiences and ideas

"Cognitive Development in Children"
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: cognitive theory
item.description:
cognitive theory

Term

cognitive theory
a grand theory of human development that focuses on changes in how people think over time
according to this theory, our thoughts shape our attitudes, beliefs and behaviours

educable

Word

educable

item.title: horizontal decalage (Piaget)
item.description:
horizontal decalage (Piaget)

Term

horizontal decalage
the idea that at each level certain concepts appear in sequence over months or even years
stages of knowledge development are sequential and discrete[^1]

[^1]: the acquisition of conservation of weight and volume build on the conservation of substance "Cognitive Development in Children …
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: Hulling
item.description:
Hulling

For a hundred years I had lain
in the bedrock
heavy, penitent, waiting.
This stone could not be wrought.
Turn it to silt, scattering in water and wind.
Till then, let me be
numb, untouched.

Then, springtime comes, looks on me and there have been a thousand springtimes. Still …
item.dc:creator: Vaishnavy Puvipalan

item.title: information-processing theory
item.description:
information-processing theory

Term

information processing theory
a perspective that figures human cognition as analogous to computational analysis of data, consisting of sensory input, connections, memory storage, and ouput
emphasizes processes of thought in contrast to the Piagetian focus on responses ^[1]

[^1]: but Piaget also offered a theory that is …

item.description:
Note Flow

Fleeting

Literature Notes

Term Notes

item.title: seriation (Piaget)
item.description:
seriation (Piaget)

#Term
seriation
the concept that things can be arranged in a logical series, such as the number sequence or the alphabet
critical for mathematics

item.title: Interpersonal Relationships Paper
item.description:
Interpersonal Relationships Paper: The Female Dating Strategy

  • Paper should be critiquing pop psych dating advice
  • FDS is an interesting angle because we're inundated with redpill/manosphere content (in psych too, lots of papers about incels) but their distaff counterparts are understudied
  • the official FDS blog uses psych in their articles …
